fields.description:
According to [our documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/MySQL+5.1] the MySQL Connector must be downloaded and moved to {{<BAMBOO_INSTALL>/atlassian-bamboo/WEB-INF/lib/}}.

This is not concise among Atlassian products. For example, in FishEye the connector must be moved to {{<FISHEYE_INST>/lib}}.
In Bamboo, the driver should be in an equivalent directory, such as {{<BAMBOO_HOME>/lib}}. 

The advantage of doing this is that users won't forget to download and move the MySQL connector file every time they upgrade Bamboo.
fields.summary: Move MySQL connector to Bamboo Home

fields.description:
h1. Overview

When we perform a "sync" in Bitbucket from an origin to a fork repository, Bamboo will trigger an automated build (as per our settings). However, it will _also_ trigger creation and initiation of all branches that have been included in the "sync", whether open, merged or closed.
fields.summary: Bitbucket / Mercurial Fork Sync causes Branch Builds of closed Branches

fields.description:
I'd like to deploy to completely different servers without having to click 'deploy' and confirm independently. 

For example, when doing releases, I want to do all the steps at the same time. I'd like as well to 'group' different environments, for example 'Dogfooding servers', 'Releasing Servers', and so on. So I could select all servers of a certain group to deploy the same release. 

Ideally, it would be similar to the 'customised' build, where you can select the manual stages you want to run with checkboxes.

fields.description:
As per https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CLOVER/%27Current%27+Report, Clover is unable to count NCLOC (non-commented lines of code) for Groovy code. 

Because of this limitation, if project contains Groovy code only, the 'Lines of code' chart always shows zero. Clover can display LOC value for Groovy language, however. 

Therefor, we could draw both NCLOC and LOC lines on a chart.
fields.summary: Clover's 'Lines of code' chart should display NCLOC + LOC

fields.description:
It would be interesting of having a feature to a webhook where Bamboo identifies what is the latest commit made and to it branch and run a build based on those information.

At moment, users require to add at least one entry as a webhook to build a particular branch in Bamboo. Due to that, every time a new Branch is created and or deleted, users are required to add/remove manually webhook entries.

1. The "main" branch gets triggered via a web hook from Github
2. Automatically build branches is enabled.

With this setup, there's no way for the trigger that cause the branches that have a change to be built. There's no way for GitHub to know what the plan keys are for each branch.

Doing a polling trigger means waiting for the poll interval to elapse; and even at 30 seconds, in our setup, this is too long, as we're using the CI server as part of development testing.

Jenkins has no problem doing this – it's able to build whatever branches are changed via a trigger notification correctly. We'll probably stick with Jenkins until Bamboo can do this.
fields.summary: Github triggering should be branch aware

fields.description:
Haven't managed to pinpoint the exact cause but symptoms
* A plan status gadget with a single plan will work, a gadget with 2 or more will fail
* Charts gadgets may or may not work depending on what they feel like.
* Turning on trusted apps allows all the gadgets to work as expected.

Debugging notes
* Trusted apps headers are in some of the requests coming from the gadgets, when they really shouldn't be.
* The gadgets are not maintaining their access-token from one request to the next, they constantly have to handshake, if the handshake is successful THAT request will work but following requests will not include the correct auth headers and will 401..
* When you have multiple plans, because its not reusing the previous token, the plan requests all need to do the handshake.  Unfortunately they all do it in parallel and wipe each others tokes...

Tested with
* Bamboo 5.5.1 + Jira 6.3
* Bamboo 5.3 + Jira 6.3 and Jira 6.1.8
* Bamboo 5.6 + Jira 6.3
fields.summary: Gadgets only works with trusted apps not 2LO

fields.description:
With plan branches, we have this problem :
 - trunk has no tests
 - branch has tests

If we configure Maven with 'The build will produce test results.' or JUnit Parser task, the trunk will fail, but if we disable tests parsing, branch will not display tests results.

It would be better to have 2 levels : 'The build MUST produce test results' (current behavior) and 'The build MAY produce test results' (will not fail if there is no tests but will parse them if they exist)
fields.summary: Allow test results to be absent

fields.description:
Hello,

we are using the hosted version of the Bamboo build server. 
As you can see in the attached screenshot, the system recognizes a hung build but does not automatically terminate the build process.
Due to this, the build pipeline is blocked and no new builds can be run anymore. Besides that, costs for running the ec2 build instance will pile up.

Is there a way to get around this restriction?
fields.summary: Hung builds won't be killed automatically

fields.description:
Bamboo will give a 'grey result' ("did not complete") to jobs that did actually complete but the server fails to save the test results.

In the case I saw, the name of one of the tests was so long that it exceeded the 4000 character limit:
{noformat}
bamboo_server=# \d test_case
                    Table "public.test_case"
        Column         |            Type             | Modifiers
-----------------------+-----------------------------+-----------
 test_case_id          | bigint                      | not null
 test_class_id         | bigint                      |
 test_case_name        | character varying(4000)     |
...
{noformat}
In this case, the test name was something like 4,700 characters long (it was automatically generated).

The errors reported in the server logs were:
{noformat}
2014-06-17 06:24:10,164 INFO [buildTailMessageListenerConnector-1] [TestsManagerImpl] Test migration to BuildResultsSummary complete for AID-AID129-JOB1-16
2014-06-17 06:24:10,167 INFO [buildTailMessageListenerConnector-1] [PlanStatePersisterImpl] AID-AID129-JOB1-16: Saving build results to disk...
2014-06-17 06:24:10,239 WARN [buildTailMessageListenerConnector-1] [JDBCExceptionReporter] SQL Error: 0, SQLState: 22001
2014-06-17 06:24:10,239 ERROR [buildTailMessageListenerConnector-1] [JDBCExceptionReporter] Batch entry 3 insert into TEST_CASE (TEST_CLASS_ID, TEST_CASE_NAME, SUCCESSFUL_RUNS, FAILED_RUNS, AVG_DURATION, FIRST_BUILD_NUM, LAST_BUILD_NUM, QUARANTINING_USERNAME, QUARANTINE_DATE, LINKED_JIRA_ISSUE, TEST_CASE_ID) values ('627737276', '(really long test name here)', '0', '0', '0', '-1', '-1', NULL, NULL, NULL, '627769903') was aborted.Call getNextException to see the cause.
{noformat}

I think that Bamboo should:
- gracefully handle the case where it cannot save a test result, perhaps with an error message on the 'tests' tab that explains why it couldn't save it.
- still show whether the build succeeded or failed (i.e. not give a grey result).
fields.summary: Bamboo reports that a job does not complete when it fails to save test results

fields.description: Much like Jenkins or Hudson has it would be great to see a single click "pre shutdown" button to disable all builds/agents/etc. so no builds tried to queue prior to a shutdown or restart.

fields.description:
I've upgraded to bamboo 5.5.1, on a windows server 2008 machine with JDK 1.8.
Unfortunately, this JDK version was not supported and Bamboo did not display a clear message that this was the issue.

I would suggest that Bamboo checks for java tool-chain compatibility at load-time, thus notifying the user if any discrepancies were found, and if any downgrades or upgrades are required.

See support ticket for more information:
https://support.atlassian.com/servicedesk/customer/bsp/installation-query-14190
fields.summary: As a user I would like Bamboo to check my machine for JDK compatibility

Also Dependency does not work for branches with the same name when using MDP if there is atleast a dependency that does not match.

fields.description:
We were alerted about the HipChat messaging being broken on JBAC. Looking at the server log, I was seeing the following stack trace:

{noformat}
2014-06-12 12:42:38,182 INFO [Thread-30] [BambooSmackClient] Connecting to InstantMessagingServerDefinitionImpl{name='Default', host='chat.hipchat.com', port=5222, username='xxxxxxx@chat.hipchat.com', resource='jira-bamboo.internal.at
lassian.com', secureConnectionRequired=true, enforceLegacySsl=false}
Exception in thread "Thread-30" java.lang.IllegalStateException: The Bamboo Smack client could not be initiated.
        at com.atlassian.bamboo.xmpp.BambooSmackClient$BambooXMPPConnection.getConnection(BambooSmackClient.java:253)
        at com.atlassian.bamboo.xmpp.BambooSmackClient$BambooXMPPConnection.syncSend(BambooSmackClient.java:239)
        at com.atlassian.bamboo.xmpp.BambooSmackClient$XmppWorkerThread.run(BambooSmackClient.java:278)
{noformat}

We don't know what caused this problem and the exception that caused the problem is ignored in the code (yay). Unfortunately, it looks like a restart is the only solution to this:
* The code is contained in bamboo core; so there is no quick win by disabling and re-enabling the plugin
* The unhandled ISE exception caused the worker thread to die; a new thread is only created when the {{BambooSmackClient}} is created - which itself is a Spring bean so it only exists once

I suggest to include at least the reason contained in the ignored exception in the ISE. Hardening the worker thread and making sure that when it dies there is a new one would be nice as well.

ATM we're running  Atlassian Bamboo version 5.6-m1 build 4402 - 15 May 14.

Note: using the test functionality on via the UI, I could see the following exception in the server log:

fields.description:
Bamboo does not work with Putty format keys and Putty is the only application that can read them natively. Before using them in Bamboo they should be converted to OpenSSH format. 

Please add more details and validation steps to Bamboo so this issue can be caught easier and faster. Currently it's impossible to find out key formats are causing the problem since there are no records/information about it in Bamboo logs.
fields.summary: Improve Bamboo logging to capture issues caused by un-supported key formats

fields.description:
It would be useful if we could specify during the execution of the build plan which version number should be used by the associated deployment plan.
At the moment the version number used in the deployment plan is managed by Bamboo, but our tools (here maven) know better which version has been released/created during the build run.
fields.summary: As a release manager, I want to be able to specify the version of the deployment project from my release plan

fields.description:
Currently the C3Po library we used accept configurations for the basic pool and the management of the pool size & connection age. It will be nice to have other configurations like the connection testing. At the moment, adding the following are neglected:

{code}
<property name="hibernate.c3p0.testConnectionOnCheckout">true</property>
<property name="hibernate.c3p0.preferredTestQuery">SELECT 1</property>
<property name="hibernate.c3p0.unreturnedConnectionTimeout">1800</property>
<property name="hibernate.c3p0.debugUnreturnedConnectionStackTraces">true</property>
{code}

ref: http://www.mchange.com/projects/c3p0/#basic_pool_configuration
fields.summary: Allow extra c3po connection pool configuration in Bamboo

fields.description:
I'm setting the scheduled backup path to somewhere outside BAMBOO_HOME (a separate filesystem). I've gone through the following procedure:

1. Temporarily pass -Dbamboo.paths.set.allowed=true on startup using JVM_SUPPORT_RECOMMENDED_ARGS;

2. Edit the scheduled backup and set the path through the GUI;

3. Remove the bamboo.paths.set.allowed property and restart Bamboo.

If I view my scheduled backup configuration at this point it looks OK.

If I change some other aspect of the configuration - click Edit, change a schedule, then Save - I would expect the backup path to remain the same, but it silently reverts to the default path under BAMBOO_HOME.

As a workaround I was going to just leave the default path and make it a symlink to the other filesystem, but when editing the job Bamboo complains  the backup path must be a relative path under the home directory.
fields.summary: Scheduled backup path reverts to default after editing scheduled backup properties

If we kick off the plan manually, it runs without any issue.

I am using
Atlassian Bamboo version 5.2 build 4003
fields.summary: Some bamboo plans do not run on cron schedule

Application Link {0} created successfully.

Confluence Version :  Atlassian Confluence 5.5

fields.description:
On our Jenkins server we use the Javadoc Plugin to publish API docs for library jobs. We use the Maven javadoc:javadoc goal to build the docs and the Jenkins plugin takes care of publishing the latest build's Javadoc on the job page.

We're migrating to Bamboo and this would be a useful feature to have on a build plan page. I know we could copy the Javadoc to a web server as a separate build task, but with no hyperlink to the Javadoc on the build plan it won't be obvious where to find it or that it even exists.
fields.summary: Publish Javadoc with build plan

fields.description:
The value of system.get.executable is missing "\git.exe" on my Bamboo system and I have been unable to edit it.

system.git.executable = C:\Users\engy.bamboo.svc\AppData\Local\Atlassian\SourceTree\git_local\bin
fields.summary: Incorrect value of system.git.executable

fields.description:
When XML report file is analyzed by the parsers, we're not expecting to get duplicate testcases and then a new occurence of a testcase with the same classname+name, Bamboo ignores the second occurrence.  Now the problem comes when in some rear cases the classname /name appear in different testsuites.

Perhaps we could implement the parsers in such a way to prefix the test cases with the testsuite names so that we don`t ignore dupes from different testsuites
fields.summary: Append the testsuite names to the test report in Junit

fields.description:
I have a build plan with a number of stages. The initial stages run automatically and the final job triggers events outside of bamboo before completing. This stage goes green at this point as it does not wait for a response but the process that has been initiated elsewhere is still running. 
The external process completes later and it then calls the bamboo api to initiate the next stage in order to complete the remaining stages of the pipeline.

So currently, we have to set the later stage as a 'Manual' stage to achieve this. However, this means that a logged in user can click the stage run button and start the second set of stages before it is ready to proceed.

I would like an option to have a manual type stage that can be triggered through the API, but does not display a run button on the web interface.
I would call this a 'Remote Triggered' stage and be a check box on the stage config like the 'Manual' option.
fields.summary: New stage config option - 'remote trigger only'

fields.description:
Hi Atlassian

With bambooo the page "All Deployment Projects" could be improve. If you have lots of projects on this page it is not so easy to distinguish the project's name from the environment's name because these two labels have the same font design. 

Thanks by advance
Jérôme
fields.summary: list of projects deployment

fields.description:
Bamboo will appear to block the addition and manipulation of local users if the "Read only  external user management" is set, even when no additional user repositories have been defined.  Security settings page are not a high-traffic area, so it can easily be overlooked.

An improvement for Bamboo will be to either clearly warn the user on the actual User and Group page that the RO checkbox has been set, and as such no manipulation is possible, or alternatively, simply disable the functionality until an external user repository is added, and maintain the correct state when they are removed or deselected.
fields.summary: Clarify read-only external management state to users
Hide passwords in ps aux for https git tasks

fields.description:
Since upgrading to Bamboo 5.5.1, many different builds are hanging at various points. I cannot determine a pattern. Sometimes they work, sometimes they hang. There doesn't seem to be any indicators in the Bamboo log. This together with BAM-14679 means that I will likely have to roll back to an earlier version. Before I do that, is there any debug setting that would help get some logging that may indicate what is going on?

Also, stopping the build does not always work. Once a couple of agents get blocked by unfinished canceling, I have to restart Bamboo.
fields.summary: Builds hanging on a regular basis after upgrade to 5.5.1

fields.description:
h3. Summary
A *disabled* artifact download task will still generate an exception and fail a build if it cannot find a successful plan result for the source plan of the shared artifact.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a plan TEST-PLAN1 which exports a shared artifact.
# Create a plan TEST-PLAN2. 
# Add an Artifact Download task to TEST-PLAN2 which downloads the shared artifact from TEST-PLAN1.
# Disable the artifact download task.
# Build TEST-PLAN2 before building TEST-PLAN1.
# Build fails with java.lang.IllegalArgumentException stating that it's "Unable to find at least one successful result for plan: TEST-PLAN1".

h3. Expected Results
Build should succeed as the artifact download task is disabled.

h3. Actual Results
The below exception is thrown in the atlassian-bamboo.log file:
{code}
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Unable to find at least one successful result for plan: TEST-PLAN1
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.artifact.ArtifactDownloaderRuntimeDataProvider.populateRuntimeTaskData(ArtifactDownloaderRuntimeDataProvider.java:90)
{code}
 
h3.Workaround
Delete the artifact download task instead of disabling it or successfully complete a build of the source plan.
fields.summary: Artifact Download tasks which are disabled can still cause an exception in Bamboo

fields.description: Much the same way you can test the connection to an external DB when starting Bamboo for the first time, it would be great to have testing functionality for repo credentials/address/etc. This way the customer can potentially receive an error message and know what's broken without needing to check the logs.
fields.summary: Add connection testing ability for linking repositories

fields.description:
Here's the scenario:
# A plan has two stages:
## Stage A creates a shared artifact
## Stage B has a task that subscribes to and uses that artifact
# [DRAFT]If the artifact definition is deleted and re-created[/DRAFT], the task in Stage B loses its link to the subscribed artifact. However, if you edit the configuration of that task, it appears to be correctly pointing to the artifact, when in reality it is not.
# The result is that at runtime, the artifact is not found by the task, and you get an error like this:

{code}Unable to find the artifact with id 606371997 in this task's context. Has an artifact subscription been configured for that artifact in this job?{code}

The workaround is simply to click Save in the consuming task's configuration, which presumably causes Bamboo to re-read the artifact drop-down and store the correct artifact ID against the task.
fields.summary: Subscribed artifact appears correct in task config but not found at runtime
JIRA issue creation popup should display all required fields

fields.description:
h4. Symptoms

Bamboo Build information in JIRA shows 401 Error.

h4. Causes

Bamboo needs to upgrade Trusted Apps to v3.0.7. Bamboo in OnDemand is failing to accept TA requests from the other instances, because they now cache the certificate that forms part of the request to reduce load. 

This means Bamboo must accept certificates up to 15 minutes old. Currently it spits its dummy if they are 2 seconds old. v3.0.7 of Trusted Apps will fix this.
fields.summary: Integration with Bamboo intermittently failing in OnDemand - returns 401 Error

fields.description:
I have multiple build projects for over a dozen different components. As Bamboo On Demand doesn't support user installable plugins, I have to rely on the use of custom scripts. Now I find myself copy-pasting scripts from one build project to another over and over again. Every time I have to make a chance, all copies have to be updated. 

It would be a very easy and powerful way to extend Bamboo without having to write plugins, if the admin could write simple shell scripts and make those reusable in build and deployment tasks. I want my scripts to show up in the admin section as "Shared scripts" next to "Shared credentials". When creating a new task I want to simply select one of those shared scripts and provide additional command line parameters if necessary. That's it. No editing or fiddling with the code, no copy-paste errors, no more updating scripts across all projects. Scripts could even be shared in the community.
fields.summary: Shareable/reusable scripts

fields.summary: NPE thrown when trying to delete deployment details of a non-existing release

fields.description:
Currently dependency management is done in a parent-to-child triggering fashion, i.e. parent plan completes and initiates child plan(s). I'd like to see an option where a child plan can be scheduled to run on a given time interval, but will only run if the parent has changed since the last time the child plan ran.

My prime example is that I have some nightly operations that I only want to do when there is a new build. This is both for "child" build plans (e.g. file system activity), as well as deployment projects (e.g. create new release).
fields.summary: Dependency Scheduling

fields.description:
When updating UPM to version 2.16.2, upgrade process gets frozen though the add-on is updated successfully. A page refresh will show version 2.16.2. 
This is tested on Postgres 9.1, Mysql 5.5 and embedded database, all of them have the exact same result.

Please refer to the public UPM bug report for more details: [JS error during UPM self-update when updating from pre-2.16.2 to 2.16.2+|https://ecosystem.atlassian.net/browse/UPM-4495].
fields.summary: UPM Upgrade to version 2.16.2 Hangs

fields.description: This is a request from a Bamboo user. He'd like to be able to see the pass/fail history of the individual jobs much like you can see the history of plans.
fields.summary: Being able to see the pass/fail history of individual jobs within a plan would be really useful.

fields.description: This has been requested by a user. He'd like to be able to see the truncated commit message as well as the person who committed the change in the history page for a plan. If it could link or have a hover popup to the full commit details it would be really useful as well.
fields.summary: Display the git commit details and not just the commit user in the history for a plan.

fields.description: Bamboo is currently able to list the branches for a plan via the REST api, but not retrieve the name of the repo itself through a similar call.  This would be useful for external scripting and reporting purposes.
fields.summary: Ability to get Repo name via REST api

fields.description: We send the build RSS feed into our IRC channel, and it would be great to get a heads up on success/failure of deployment plans as well.
fields.summary: RSS feed for Deployment plans

fields.description: Whenever I try to cancel an SVN checkout task, it never stops the checkout, and only notes in the logs that I attempted to stop it. Subsequent attempts add new notes to the log and sometimes lock the SVN account.
fields.summary: Unable to cancel SVN checkout task

fields.description: We would like to have the option to quarantine all failing tests in a build, or at least have the option to automatically quarantine any test failures in order to get a build to complete following first checkout. With dozens of failures this is tedious, especially since it requires us to quarantine each failure individually.
fields.summary: Quarantine all test failures

fields.description:
Navigate to https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO052/Bamboo+FAQ

Click the first link on the page (What is Continuous Integration?).

Result is a 404 page.
fields.summary: Bamboo documentation link results in 404 error

fields.description:
We like the Quarantine function very much.
In our current workflow, for most of the quarantined tests there is a linked JIRA issue.
However, sometimes we do not want to create them and want just to "silence" the test for some period of time.

It would be nice to have the possibility to also add a "comment" to the test, or during quarantining it.
fields.summary: Add commenting possibility to Quarantining tests

fields.description:
Given that we are disabling authentication, it also seems a bit odd that we would poll to see what agents are available in the first place - just to forget about them.

Suggest that we don't poll prior to forgetting agents.
fields.summary: Dont poll existing agents when disabling authentication

fields.description:
I have multiple plans on my Bamboo server which generate artifacts, and then a downstream plan which downloads those artifacts and packages them together for distribution.  The downstream plan has Artifact Download tasks in the stage and use the shared artifacts to download.  If the upstream build does not produce an artifact for some reason, the downstream build is not failing when it tries to download the artifact.  The log for the plan says it downloaded the artifact, but there is nothing in the folder it downloaded to.  

Everything works if I do not have build issues, I am trying to have the build fail if the artifact is not present for distribution packaging.  Right now I get false positives because it says the build was successful and I go to download it, and it is missing artifacts.  It should have failed on the download task for the missing shared artifact.

Looking at the log, it says all 5 artifacts downloaded.
simple	27-May-2014 20:45:15	Starting task 'download graphite artifact' of type 'com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.bamboo-artifact-downloader-plugin:artifactdownloadertask'
simple	27-May-2014 20:45:15	Preparing to download plan result EM-GRAPHITE-10 artifact: Shared artifact: [infinidb_em-graphite.tar.gz], pattern: [infinidb-em-graphite-*.tar.gz] anchored at: [target]
simple	27-May-2014 20:45:15	Artifact [infinidb_em-graphite.tar.gz] downloaded successfully in 0s to: /build/packages/
simple	27-May-2014 20:45:15	Finished task 'download graphite artifact'
simple	27-May-2014 20:45:15	Starting task 'download collectd artifact' of type 'com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.bamboo-artifact-downloader-plugin:artifactdownloadertask'
simple	27-May-2014 20:45:15	Preparing to download plan result EM-COLLECTD-36 artifact: Shared artifact: [infinidb_em-collectd.tar.gz], pattern: [infinidb-em-collectd-*.tar.gz] anchored at: [target]
simple	27-May-2014 20:45:15	Artifact [infinidb_em-collectd.tar.gz] downloaded successfully in 0s to: /build/packages/
simple	27-May-2014 20:45:15	Finished task 'download collectd artifact'
simple	27-May-2014 20:45:15	Starting task 'download server artifact' of type 'com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.bamboo-artifact-downloader-plugin:artifactdownloadertask'
simple	27-May-2014 20:45:15	Preparing to download plan result EM-EMSERVER-93 artifact: Shared artifact: [server.tar.gz], pattern: [infinidb_em-server-*.tar.gz] anchored at: [target]
simple	27-May-2014 20:45:16	Artifact [server.tar.gz] downloaded successfully in 0s to: /build/packages/
simple	27-May-2014 20:45:16	Finished task 'download server artifact'
simple	27-May-2014 20:45:16	Starting task 'download python-stack artifact' of type 'com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.bamboo-artifact-downloader-plugin:artifactdownloadertask'
simple	27-May-2014 20:45:16	Preparing to download plan result EM-PYTHON-31 artifact: Shared artifact: [python-stack.tar.gz], pattern: [infinidb_em-python_stack-*.tar.gz] anchored at: [target]
simple	27-May-2014 20:45:16	Artifact [python-stack.tar.gz] downloaded successfully in 0s to: /build/packages/
simple	27-May-2014 20:45:16	Finished task 'download python-stack artifact'
simple	27-May-2014 20:45:16	Starting task 'download emtools' of type 'com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.bamboo-artifact-downloader-plugin:artifactdownloadertask'
simple	27-May-2014 20:45:16	Preparing to download plan result EM-TOOLS-80 artifact: Shared artifact: [infinidb-em-tools.tar.gz], pattern: [infinidb-em-tools-*.tar.gz] anchored at: [target]
simple	27-May-2014 20:45:16	Artifact [infinidb-em-tools.tar.gz] downloaded successfully in 0s to: /build/packages/
simple	27-May-2014 20:45:16	Finished task 'download emtools'
simple	27-May-2014 20:45:16	Starting task 'package' of type 'com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.scripttask:task.builder.script'
command	27-May-2014 20:45:16	Beginning to execute external process for build 'Enterprise Manager - infinidb-em - Default Job #195 (EM-EM-JOB1-195)'\n ... running command line: \n/bin/sh ./package.sh\n ... in: /mnt/bamboo-ebs/bamboo-agent/build-dir/EM-EM-JOB1\n


Looking at the directory:
[bamboo@ip-172-31-12-129 EM-EM-JOB1]$ ls -la build/packages
total 1004
drwxrwxr-x 2 bamboo bamboo   4096 May 28 01:45 .
drwxrwxr-x 3 bamboo bamboo   4096 May 28 01:45 ..
-rw-rw-r-- 1 bamboo bamboo 871213 May 28 01:45 infinidb-em-collectd-5.4.1.tar.gz
-rw-rw-r-- 1 bamboo bamboo    909 May 28 01:45 infinidb-em-graphite-0.9.10.tar.gz
-rw-rw-r-- 1 bamboo bamboo 132247 May 28 01:45 infinidb-em-tools-BETA.tar.gz
[bamboo@ip-172-31-12-129 EM-EM-JOB1]$ 

Only 3 of them downloaded.  

Is the issue because of the wildcard pattern?  Or is the issue because I have my artifact names with a .tar.gz at the end and it is confusing it for a filename?

The upstream build says it published an artifact, but when I look at the Artifacts tab for the build, it says no files found.
simple	27-May-2014 20:45:11	Running post build plugin 'Artifact Copier'
simple	27-May-2014 20:45:11	Publishing an artifact: server.tar.gz
simple	27-May-2014 20:45:11	Finished publishing of artifact Shared artifact: [server.tar.gz], pattern: [infinidb_em-server-*.tar.gz] anchored at: [target] in 0s

It would be ideal that this upstream build failed for not having an artifact found by the artifact definition.   

I am sure its a misconfiguration, I have read the docs several times and can't see anything I am doing wrong.  Also I am not seeing example of what a 'subscribed artifact failure' is, I see the warning note when I mark an artifact shared, but what triggers that failure.  That is probably what I want :)
fields.summary: Child plans do not fail if artifact missing

fields.description:
Rather than having to enter in my GitHub username/password into Bamboo it would be better if Bamboo generated a key pair so I could register Bamboo's public key with GitHub or generate a GitHub auth token and register it with Bamboo.
h3. Update from Atlassian. 10 September 2020

Since Bamboo 7.1.2 users can provide Github Personal access token instead of password for Github integration. SSH generation is not support yet
fields.summary: Support GitHub tokens and keys

fields.description:
Use case:

I need to run integration tests (e.g. selenium tests) after deploy on some of configured environments. 

Now it is not possible. 

Could you implement some trigger to run build tasks by the success release/deploy, e.g. to run selenium tests on the new release? 

BTW, do you think about adopting the workflow engine (e.g. from Jira) to customize the build/deploy/test/promote process?
fields.summary: Trigger build job from deployment
